awd_titl_txt: Extraction of Information from Scientific Simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
Numerical simulations are a cornerstone of the modern scientific process, and considerable expense and energy, both literally and figuratively, is put into simulations. The two objectives of this project are to (1) shorten simulation time, and (2) ask new questions of the data given the output of an existing simulation (but not its full history) in order to avoid running a new simulation.  To shorten simulation time, a naive approach leads to less accurate estimates of certain variables that are used for both prediction of new material properties and for validation of numerical models against known properties. This program investigates super-resolution methods that do not suffer this loss of accuracy. The second objective records appropriate randomized snapshots or "sketches" from simulations.  Because it may not be known in advance which variables should be directly calculated, this program develops techniques to use the sketches to estimate variables that were not originally calculated. The technique is designed to "future-proof" simulations, and gives datasets a second chance at being useful without requiring a new simulation to be run. Achieving either or both objectives in this project will lead to fewer unnecessary computer simulations, saving energy and reducing impact on the environment.

This project brings together ideas from physical chemistry, high-performance computing, optimization, machine learning, digital signal processing, and time-series statistics. More specifically, the first objective is to estimate spectral variables from a shortened simulation. Shortening the time range usually has the effect of broadening the spectral lines. Under appropriate assumptions on the spectra, recent advances in harmonic analysis show that by solving a semi-definite program, one can super-resolve the spectral lines. These advances have been limited to signal-processing applications, and with appropriate modification, they will have a great impact on spectral estimation from simulations.  The project will develop efficient algorithms to tackle this problem, as well as show how it can be adapted to the situation of scientific computing, and theoretically extended to correctly handle uncertainty. The second objective is compressive parameter estimation, which has only recently been explored and mainly in the context of digital signal processing. The project will develop particular estimators for given statistics, as well as explore a general approach to apply to a broad class of statistics. The approach for storing snapshots of data will be applied primarily to magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) simulations of solar convection, a field of great importance due to the effect of the sun's weather on cosmic rays and photons incident on Earth.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Scientific simulations often model a phenomena over the course of time (such as the motions of particles over 1 ms), and from this time series data, one can compute spectra, which are the frequency modes present. Spectra can be used to validate computational models against experiments, or validate theory against computation, or to make predictions of material characteristics.  To compute the spectra accurately, a long simulation time is needed, and simulation time is usually directly proportional to computation time and energy consumption.

This projects tackles accurate estimation of spectra from scientific simulation, specifically looking at three questions:

(1) can spectra be computed accurately from less data (i.e., shorter simulation times)? In particular, which post-processing methods are best?

(2) can spectra be computed accurately from sub-sampled data, as in time-dependent density-functional theory (TDDFT) simulations used for polarizability? In TDDFT, only certain molecular configurations are fully characterized, leading to irregularly spaced time data.

(3) can the simulation data itself be compressed, in a manner more clever than just sub-sampling time, so that arbitrary 2nd order statistics (those based on 2nd order moments, such as autocorrelation and the power spectrum) can be later recovered after the simulation is over? That is, can we find "future-proof" sampling scheme that works no matter what type of 2nd order analysis is later requested?

Furthemore, in introducing randmized techniques for these goals,

(4) can these techniques be used in other domains, such as stochastic optimization methods?

Through work with 6 students (1 undergraduate, 1 masters student, 1 full-time PhD student and 3 part-time PhD students), we made excellent progress. The following are the intellectual merit results:

Working on the problem of using shorter-time, we focused on parametric methods for specific problems of Methanol spectra, and surveyed existing methods and then provided improved variants. This became a masters thesis [1].

To address simulations that have irregularly spaced time data, and to generally improve resolution of the spectra, we developed a novel post-processing method based on semi-definite programming, and showed how it can be used to give high-resolution results. Results are in the Asilomar conference paper [2].

For the purposes of compression and future-proof storage, we show that there are methods based on randomized dimensionality reduction, or randomized sketches, that drastically outperform time sub-sampling based methods while still efficient to apply in real-time to simulations. This work is in the JCP journal paper [3].

Finally, the randomized sketching idea can be extended to randomized optimization methods, which we did in [4-5]. This also provided a venue for an undergraduate student to become involved in the problem, working on optimal placement of magnetic sensors used in Magnetoencephalography (MEG) brfain imaging. By using the randomized optimization methods, she was able to systematically find sensor locations that result in the best signal.

For broader impact results, the intellectual contributions themselves can lead to less computer simulation time, which leads to faster science and less energy use.

Furthermore, the grant involved many male and female students of various stages: undergraduates, masters, and PhD students.  These students were active participants in a research environment and learned much about the scientific method and world of professional academics, in addition to general purpose mentoring by the PI and senior graduate students. Two of the PhD students have since graduated and taken postdocs; the undergraduate is interested in pursuing a masters thesis on a related topic.

 

References:

[1] A comparison of spectral estimation techniques, Marc Thomson, 2019, Masters thesis at University of Colorado; code at github.

[2] Nuclear Norm Based Spectrum Estimation for Molecular Dynamic Simulations. Shuang Li, Stephen Becker, Michael Wakin. In Asilomar conference on Signals, Systems and Computers

[3] Spectral estimation from simulations via sketching. Zhishen Huang, Stephen Becker. Journal of Computational Physics, 2021. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcp.2021.110686

[4] Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics with Variance Reduction. Zhishen Huang, Stephen Becker. IJCNN2021 (International Joint Conference on Neural Networks).

[5] A stochastic subspace approach to gradient-free optimization in high dimensions. David Kozak, Stephen Becker, Alireza Doostan, Luis Tenorio. Computational Optimization and Applications, 2021. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10589-021-00271-w
